content.webTitle: Are you taking part or affected by South Western rail strikes?

fields.headline: Are you taking part or affected by South Western rail strikes?
fields.bodyText: On Monday 2 December, a month of strike action by South Western Railway (SWR) staff began across its entire network. RMT members will walk out every day of the month apart from 1 December, 12 December – election day – and 25 and 26 December. SWR is one of the busiest commuter lines in the country – used by around 600,000 passengers daily – and all who use the service are expected to be affected. SWR has published a detailed strike timetable with around half of the weekday trains running however these services are expected to be more packed than usual. The union has taken action over a long-term dispute regarding the future presence of guards on all trains, even though SWR have made multiple public pledges to keep guards on trains talks between the union and company have recently broken down. The RMT has also begun a chain of strikes for seven successive Saturdays, running through December on West Midlands services. If you have been affected by the West Midland strikes, tell us about it here. Share your views and experiences We want to hear about how the strikes have affected you or will affect you in the weeks to come. Are you a member of the RMT union taking part in the strikes? What are your main reasons for doing so? Are you you are a commuter who uses SWR? How do you expect your journey to be impacted? How do you feel about the strikes taking place? You can get in touch by filling in the encrypted form below, anonymously if you wish. Only the Guardian will see your responses and one of our journalists may be in touch for more information. You can also get in touch via WhatsApp by clicking here or adding the contact +44(0)7867825056. If you’re having trouble using the form, click here. Read terms of service here.
